name: Collaborative Problem Solving (CPS)
summary: A parent–child intervention that emphasizes empathy, collaboration, and skill-building rather than punishment to address challenging behaviors in children.
description: Collaborative Problem Solving (CPS), developed by Dr. Ross Greene and Dr. Stuart Ablon, is a parent-training and therapeutic approach designed to help children with oppositional, defiant, or explosive behaviors. CPS is based on the principle that 'children do well if they can,' emphasizing that challenging behaviors arise from lagging cognitive skills such as flexibility, frustration tolerance, and problem-solving. Instead of relying on traditional consequences or rewards, CPS engages children and caregivers in a structured problem-solving process to build skills and strengthen relationships. It is widely applied in clinical, educational, and family contexts.

contraindications: Contexts requiring immediate safety interventions for severe aggression
clinical_metadata.safety_profile: Safe and non-invasive. No known adverse effects.
clinical_metadata.evidence_level: Moderate—supported by randomized controlled trials and implementation studies in schools and clinics.
clinical_metadata.research_support: Evidence suggests CPS improves parent–child relationships, reduces oppositional behavior, and enhances emotional regulation.

sections.text: CPS posits that challenging behavior results from lagging cognitive skills rather than willful defiance. The intervention helps parents and children collaboratively identify problems, express perspectives, and generate mutually satisfactory solutions. This approach reduces power struggles and builds skills in flexibility, frustration tolerance, and problem-solving.

sections.preparation: Assessment of child’s behavioral challenges, caregiver stress, and family dynamics.
procedure: Psychoeducation for parents about lagging skills vs. willful misbehavior.
Teaching caregivers to use empathy, active listening, and collaborative dialogue.
Guided problem-solving conversations with the child to address specific challenges.
Role-playing and homework practice to generalize skills.

sections.pre_session: Check-in on recent behavioral challenges and parent–child interactions.
sections.treatment_phase: Skill-building, guided collaborative conversations, modeling problem-solving.
sections.post_session: Assign parent–child practice tasks at home.

immediate: Improved parent understanding of child needs

common: Temporary frustration when adjusting to new interaction style
uncommon: Resistance from child if inconsistent implementation

absolute: Immediate safety concerns requiring crisis management
relative: Families with low engagement or unwillingness to collaborate

ideal_candidates: Children with oppositional or explosive behaviors
Families motivated to change conflict dynamics
Parents seeking non-punitive behavior management strategies
screening_required: Assessment for ODD, ADHD, or disruptive behavior
Evaluation of parent readiness and family environment

practitioner: Therapists or parent coaches trained in CPS model

studies: Greene RW, Ablon JS. (2006). Treating Explosive Kids: The Collaborative Problem-Solving Approach.
Ollendick TH et al. (2016). Randomized controlled trial of Collaborative Problem Solving for ODD.
sections.limitations: Evidence base smaller than CBT or PMT; requires consistent caregiver participation.

sections.insurance_coverage: Often covered under family therapy or parent training benefits
sections.cost_effectiveness: Cost-effective compared to long-term disruptive behavior management costs

sections.adhd: Can be adapted to address attentional difficulties alongside behavior.
sections.autism-spectrum: Used with modifications for problem-solving flexibility.
sections.school-settings: Widely implemented in classrooms and special education programs.

items: Focuses on building lagging skills, not enforcing compliance.
Strong emphasis on empathy and parent–child collaboration.
Complementary to behavioral and family-based interventions.

seo.title: Collaborative Problem Solving (CPS)
seo.description: Collaborative Problem Solving (CPS) is a family-based therapy approach for children with oppositional or disruptive behaviors, emphasizing empathy, collaboration, and skill-building over punishment.
